abstract_summ: We describe our institutional experience with COVID‐19 among ten SOT patients, including the clinical presentation, treatment modalities, and outcomes of seven renal transplant recipients, one liver transplant recipient, one heart transplant recipient, and one lung transplant recipient.Our department had formulated detailed prevention and control measures, mainly including kidney transplant outpatient management, kidney transplantation ward management, management of kidney transplant surgery, dialysis management of patients waiting for kidney transplantation, personal protection of medical staff, and follow‐up management of discharged patients after kidney transplantation.CONCLUSIONS During surge outbreaks, kidney transplant patients with even mild symptoms have a high likelihood of COVID-19 disease and most will worsen requiring hospitalization for supportive measures.After a median of 10 days, 13 kidney transplant recipients were discharged, 2 were hospitalized in non- ICU, 1 was in ICU, and 2 patients had died.Three patients died (30%), and 5 (50%) developed acute kidney injury.

title_abstract_phrases: We describe our institutional experience with COVID‐19 among ten SOT patients, including the clinical presentation, treatment modalities, and outcomes of seven renal transplant recipients, one liver transplant recipient, one heart transplant recipient, and one lung transplant recipient.In this report, we are trying to summarize available evidence about different aspects of the management of liver transplant candidates and recipients in the era of COVID-19.SARS‐CoV‐2 infection in two patients following recent lung transplantationSevere acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS‐CoV‐2) that causes Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19) has become a world spreading health problem with pandemic character.Prolonged SARS‐CoV‐2 shedding and mild course of COVID‐19 in a patient after recent heart transplantationIn the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID‐19) pandemic, organ transplant recipients are considered to be at high risk for unfavorable outcome.Further study is needed to guide immunosuppression management in OHT recipients affected by COVID-19.Threatening drug‐drug interaction in a kidney transplant patient with Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID‐19)During the novel coronavirus pandemic, organ transplant recipients represent a frail susceptible category due to long‐term immunosuppressive therapy.Our department had formulated detailed prevention and control measures, mainly including kidney transplant outpatient management, kidney transplantation ward management, management of kidney transplant surgery, dialysis management of patients waiting for kidney transplantation, personal protection of medical staff, and follow‐up management of discharged patients after kidney transplantation.
